--Use triple layer mask and sanitizer.
--Isolate yourself in a well ventilated room.
--Monitor temperature and oxygen regularly.
--Take rest and drink a lot of fluids to maintain adequate hydration.
--Perform warm water gargles or take steam inhalation twice a day.
--Seek immediate medical attention if you find difficulty in breathing.

--Medications such as paracetamol and ibuprofen may help to ease discomfort for adults
--Drink plenty of fluids, particularly water.
--Sponge exposed skin with tepid water.
--Avoid alcohol, tea and coffee as these drinks can cause slight dehydration
--Consult a doctor.

--Eating carrots is good for your vision.
--Exercises:Hold your pointer finger a few inches away from your eye.
--Focus on your finger.
--Slowly move your finger away from your face, holding your focus.
--Look away for a moment, into the distance.
--Focus on your outstretched finger and slowly bring it back toward your eye.

--Your body needs rest to heal.
--Stay hydrated.
--Honey may help coughs in adults and children who are older than age 1. Try it in hot tea.
--Salt-water gargle.
--Ginger may ease a dry or asthmatic cough, as it has anti-inflammatory properties.
--Steam Inhalation can help you to get rid of cold.

--Take steam using eucalyptus oil.
--Avoid pollen,pollution,dust and smoke.
--Doing Bhramari Pranayama everyday helps you to cure asthama.

--Avoid foods with added sugars.
--Try an Omega-3 supplement
--Consult a doctor immediately.
--Doing Vajrasana improves liver functionality.

--Close eyes,ears,mouth with 'index-middle',thumbs and ring-little fingers respectively.
--Take a deep breath and exhale with a soft humming sound like the bees.

--Sit in padmasana or Sukhasana.
--Close the right nostril,Forcefully and rapidly breathe from the left nostril twenty times.
--Do the same on right side twenty times.
--This is one round.Practice 1 to 3 rounds in summer and 3 to 5 in winters.
--Should be done by persons with weak constitution / poor lung capacity /eye or ear complaints / blood pressure.

Sashankasana-the rabbit pose:
--Sit in Vajrasana,inhailing  raise arms, while exhailing bend forward (arms should remain straight and near the ears).
--Place forehead and forearms on the ground.
--Breath normally 10 times , slowly come back while inhailing , bring down hands and place on things.
--This can be repeated around 5 times.
--To be avoided by persons with spinal discherniation, vertigo and high blood pressure.

Vajrasana:
--Sit on your knees with a straight posture and upright spine, feet should rest flat on the ground with soles turned upward.
--Focus on your breathing.
--Avoid doing in case of any leg or knee injury.
--Good for digestion and liver function.

Salabhasana-the grasshopper pose:
--Lie on your stomach with the chin stretched and touching the ground.
--Keep the hands on the side and bring them under the legs to support them.
--Inhale slowly and deeply and lift the legs as high as possible.
--It is a back bend, or spine stretch, utilizing the strength of the upper and middle back.
--Should not be done by pregnant women and those who have had any abdominal surgery in the recent past or having spinal injuries.

Sukhasana-lotus posture:
--The 'Simple Cross-Legged Pose' is intended to be comfortable and calming.
--Sitting upright with your spine aligned also reduces stress and anxiety.

Makarasana-the crocodile pose:
--Lie on the ground face down and both legs stretched out.
--Catch the headwith the arms or the face with the palms as given above.
